questions.text: Which of the following agency provide Seed and manure in Applied Nutrition programme?
questions.solution:
UNICEF is known for providing seed and manure as part of the Applied Nutrition Programme.

APPLIED NUTRITION PROGRAMME:

The Applied Nutrition Programme is an attempt at production of various types of protective foods by the community for the community. UNICEF is assisting in the implementation of the Applied Nutrition Programme in the form of implements, seeds, manure and water supply equipment, along with FAO. Wherever land is available, the facilities provided by the UNICEF should be utilized in developing school gardens. The produce may be utilized in the school feeding programmes as well as for nutrition education. The ANP was first implemented in Orissa and Andhra Pradesh in 1962. By 1973, the whole country was covered by the scheme. This programme till date is the best conceived nutrition programme. The programme was initiated as a centrally sponsored scheme but now is implemented by the states.

Objectives:

  • To make people conscious of their nutritional needs,
  • To increase production of nutritious foods and its consumption and
  • To provide supplementary nutrition to vulnerable groups through local production of food.
  • The programme aimed at the approach of "self reliance" to be developed at the community and individual level.

Beneficiaries:

  • Children between 3-6 years
  • Pregnant and lactating mothers.

Activities: ANP envisaged production of nutritious bod by people themselves and to be consumed by them to improve their own nutritional status. Poultry farming, horticulture, beehive keeping, kitchen gardening and nutrition education were main activities in the programme. The supplementary nutrition was provided to children and women beneficiaries.

Organisation: The programme is implemented under the supervision of block development officer. The Balsevikas with the help of a helper undertake the programme activities at the village/community level.

Reference:

https://www.nin.res.in/academics/notifications/Prospectus%20MSc%20(AN)%20&%20(SN)%20-%202021-23.pdf,

questions.text: Copper T is contraindicated in:
questions.solution:
Copper T (IUD) is contraindicated in cases of trophoblastic disease, which includes conditions like molar pregnancy (where there is abnormal growth of trophoblasts, the cells that normally develop into the placenta). In such conditions, the use of Copper T can potentially exacerbate the situation and is therefore contraindicated.

IUDs

CONTRAINDICATIONS

  1. ABSOLUTE :
    • Suspected pregnancy
    • Pelvic inflammatory disease
    • Vaginal bleeding of undiagnosed etiology
    • Cancer of the cervix, uterus or adnexa and other pelvic tumours
    • Previous ectopic pregnancy.
    • Malignant trophoblastic disease or known pelvic tuberculosis
  2. RELATIVE :
    • Anemia
    • Menorrhagia
    • History of PID since last pregnancy
    • Purulent cervical discharge
    • Distortions of the uterine cavity due to congenital malformations, fibroids etc
    • Unmotivated person.

questions.text: School health is the responsibility of
questions.solution:
School health programs are generally the responsibility of the Primary Health Centre (PHC). PHCs are designed to provide comprehensive health care to the community, including preventive, promotive, curative, and rehabilitative services, and often include school health services as part of their mandate.

Therefore, the correct answer is: (B): PHC

SCHOOL HEALTH ADMINISTRATION

The general health services in India are administered largely through the primary health centres in the rural areas, where the bulk of India's population lives. School health service is therefore an important function of the primary health centres:

  1. Primary health centres: The primary health centres are charged with the responsibility of administering school health service within their jurisdiction. It requires a whole-time, medical officer to cover 5,000 to 6,000 children a year. The School Health Committee has therefore recommended that the staff of the primary health centres should be augmented by additional staff to carry out effectively the school health programme.
  2. School Health Committees: The School Health Committee in India recommended the formation of school health committees at the village level, block level, district level, state level and national level. These Committees should mobilize community resources and make the school health programme continuous and self-supporting. The National School Health Council will be an advisory and coordinating body.

SCHOOL HEALTH PROGRAMME

  • Introduced in 2018 under Ayushman Bharat
  • Teachers act as "Health and Wellness Ambassadors"
  • Children act as "Health and Wellness Messengers" in the society
  • Health and Wellness Day in the school: Tuesday

Services given:

questions.text: Maize diet consumption is associated with which vitamin deficiency?
questions.solution:
Maize (corn) consumption is associated with a deficiency in:

(C): Niacin (Vitamin B3)

Maize, particularly when consumed as a staple diet without adequate processing (such as nixtamalization), can lead to niacin deficiency. Niacin deficiency can result in a condition known as pellagra, which includes symptoms such as dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia, and potentially death if left untreated.

Therefore, the correct answer is: (C): Niacin (B3)

NIACIN/NICOTINIC ACID

It is essential for the metabolism of carbohydrate, fat and protein. It is also essential for the normal functioning of the skin, intestinal and nervous systems. This vitamin differs from the other vitamins of the B-complex group in that an essential amino acid, tryptophan serves as its precursor.

Sources

Foods rich in niacin and/or tryptophan are liver, kidney meat, poultry, fish, legumes and groundnut. Milk is a poor source of niacin but its proteins are rich in tryptophan which is converted in the body into niacin(about 60mg of tryptophan is required to result in 1mg of niacin). The vitamin is resistant to heating.

Deficiency

  • Niacin deficiency results in pellagra. Pellagra is common in maize/jowar eating populations. Limiting amino acid in maize is Tryptophan. Amino-acid imbalance caused by an excess of leucine is the cause of pellagra in both jowar and maize eaters. Excess of leucine appears to interfere in the conversion of tryptophan to niacin. In maize, niacin occurs in "bound" form unavailable to the consumer
  • The disease is characterized by three D's -diarrhoea, dermatitis and dementia. In addition glossitis and stomatitis usually occur.
  • The dermatitis is bilaterally symmetrical and is found only on those surfaces of the body exposed to sunlight, such as back of the hands, lower legs, face and neck. The cutaneous lesions consist of a pigmented rash aggravated by sunlight esp. neck when it is known as 'Casal's Necklace'. More acute cases may progress to vesiculation, ulceration and secondary infection. Classically, the erythema progresses to roughening and keratosis with scaling.
  • Gauntlet sign of pellagra: Severe photo dermatitis leading to hyperpigmentation and thickening of skin on back of the hands.
    Mental changes may also occur which include depression, irritability and delirium. In most chronic forms, posterolateral cord degeneration and peripheral nerve lesions are seen. Prevention
  • Pellagra is a preventable disease. A good mixed diet containing milk and/or meat is universally regarded as an essential part of prevention and treatment. Avoidance of total dependence on maize or sorghum is an important preventive measure. Pellagra is a disease of poverty. Given modern knowledge and opportunities for economic, agricultural and social development, there is every reason to hope that this disease could be eliminated
  • Nixtamalization: Maize/corn is treated with lime(alkali), niacin will become bioavailable.

Maize diet is poor in tryptophan which is required for Niacin production in the body. Hence, Maize diet consumption is associated with Pellagra.

questions.text: Which among these is a type A bioterrorism agent?
questions.solution:
Bacillus anthracis, the causative agent of anthrax, is classified as a Category A bioterrorism agent by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Category A agents are those that pose the highest risk to national security and public health because they can be easily disseminated or transmitted from person to person, result in high mortality rates, and have the potential for major public health impact.

Nipah virus, Coxiella burnetii (the causative agent of Q fever), and Clostridium perfringens are not classified as Category A bioterrorism agents.

BIOTERRORISM

Bioterrorism, as defined by the Centre for Disease Control and Prevention, is the deliberate release, by attackers, of an agent that causes one or more of a variety of different diseases.

Categories: Based on the risk to national security, the agents have been categorised as A, B and C. These disease agents exist in nature(with the exception of smallpox, which has been eradicated in the wild), but they could be manipulated to make them more dangerous.

In the options given, Bacillus anthracis belongs to category A agents. Clostridium perforingens and Coxiella burnetti belongs to category B agents and Nipah virus belongs to category C agents.

Reference: https://emergency.cdc.gov/agent/agentlist-category.asp#a , Bioterrorism Agents/Diseases, An official website of CDC.

questions.text: As per the NTEP, high priority TB-HIV District is defined as
questions.solution:
Under the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP) in India, a high priority TB-HIV district is defined as having: > 10% population of known HIV+ve among TB patients tested for HIV in the district

NTEP CAREGORISATION OF DISTRICTS

questions.text: Match the following for Japanese encephalitis
questions.solution:
JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS

Japanese encephalitis (JE) is a mosquito-borne encephalitis caused by a group B arbovirus (Flavivirus) and transmitted by culicine mosquitoes. It is a zoonotic disease, i.e., infecting mainly animals and incidentally man. The envelope glycoprotein of the JE virus contains specific as well as cross-reactive, neutralizing epitopes. Japanese B encephalitis is the leading cause of viral encephalitis in Asia, including India

EPIDEMIOLOGICAL FEATURES

CYCLES OF TRANSMISSION

  1. Pig-Mosquito-Pig
  2. The Ardeid bird-Mosquito-Ardeid bird

Transmission occurs principally in rural agricultural location where flooding irrigation is practised. Transmission is seasonal and mainly related to the rainy season in South-East Asia Region. JE transmission intensifies during the rainy season, when vector population increases.

HOSTS

  • The disease is transmitted to man by the bite of infected mosquitoes. Man is an incidental 'dead-end' host. Man to man transmission has not so far been recorded.
  • Animal hosts: Among the animal hosts, pigs have been incriminated as the major vertebrate hosts for JE virus. Infected pigs do not manifest any overt symptoms of illness but circulate the virus so that mosquitoes get infected and can transmit the virus to man. The pigs are thus considered as 'amplifiers' of the virus Cattle and buffaloes may also be infected with the JE virus; although they may not be natural hosts of JE virus, they act as 'mosquito attractants'. Horses are the only domestic animals so far known which show signs of encephalitis due to JE virus infection.
  • Birds hosts: Some species of birds such as pond herons; cattle egrets and perhaps poultry and ducks appear to be involved in the natural history of JE virus.

MOSQUITO VECTORS

Culicine mosquitoes, notably C. tritaeniorhynchus, C. vishnui and C. gelidus along with some anophelines have been incriminated as the vectors of JE. Among these, C.tritaeniorhynchus and vishnui has been implicated as the most important vector in South India. C. tritaeniorhynchus is the major vector worldwide including India. C. vishnui is the next common vector found in India. These mosquitoes generally breed in irrigated rice fields, shallow ditches and pools. The rice fields are probably the most important breeding places. These mosquitoes are zoophilic, feeding primarily on vertebrate hosts.

questions.text: Best quantitative method to study previous research studies is
questions.solution:
The best quantitative method to study previous research studies is:

(B): Meta-analysis

Meta-analysis is a statistical technique that combines the results of multiple scientific studies. It provides a quantitative approach to synthesizing the findings from various studies, allowing researchers to draw more robust conclusions by increasing the overall sample size and improving the power of the analysis.

META-ANALYSIS

  • Steps in carrying out meta-analysis include:
  • Systematically combining results of previous research to arrive at a conclusion using statistical analysis.
  • Meta-analysis differs from most medical and epidemiological studies in that no new data are collected. Instead, results from previous studies are combined.
  • Meta-analysis is defined as the statistical synthesis of the data from separate but similar (comparable) studies, leading to a quantifiable summary of the pooled results to identify the overall trend.
    1. Formulating the problem and study design;
    2. Identifying relevant studies;
    3. Excluding poorly conducted studies or those with major methodological flaws; and
    4. Measuring, combining and interpreting the results.
  • Another important step is measuring the results of the studies on a single scale. This allows comparisons to be made between studies even if they used different measures of outcome.
  • Meta-analysis is a relatively new scientific method; research into the best techniques to use is still ongoing and expanding into new areas.
  • Drawback: Publication bias
  • Meta analysis is known as Gold standard study design
  • Systematic reviews: Systematically combining result of previous research to arrive at a conclusion without statistical analysis

questions.text: Which among the following is a non-parametric test:
questions.solution:
The Friedman test is a non-parametric test used to detect differences in treatments across multiple test attempts. It is an alternative to the repeated measures ANOVA when the assumptions of normality or homogeneity of variances are not met.


Here, Friedman's test is the non parametric counterpart of Repeated ANOVA test.

questions.text: All are helpful in covid 19 prevention except
questions.solution:
All the options listed are generally helpful in the prevention of COVID-19, but in different contexts. However, among the options provided, the one that might be considered less directly helpful for everyday COVID-19 prevention practices for the general public is:

(B): 1% Glutaraldehyde

Here's why:

  • 70% ethanol (A): Effective as a hand sanitizer for killing the virus on hands and surfaces.
  • Hand washing (C): Critical for removing and killing the virus on hands.
  • Use of mask (D): Important for preventing the spread of respiratory droplets that may contain the virus.

1% Glutaraldehyde is a potent disinfectant used mainly in healthcare settings for sterilizing medical equipment. It is not typically used for general hand hygiene or surface disinfection in everyday settings due to its toxicity and potential health hazards if not used properly. Thus, while it is effective as a disinfectant, it is not commonly used for COVID-19 prevention in routine, non-medical contexts.

questions.text: For a population of 10,000, sex ratio of more than 1000 implies-
questions.solution:
Sex ratio is number of females as per 1000 males in the population

A sex ratio of more than 1000 indicates that for every 1000 males, there are > 1000 females. That means more than 50% are females. Therefore, if the total population is 10000, and the sex ratio is more than 1000, it means that the number of females are more than 5000 and males are less than 5000

questions.text: Community health centre covering a population of
questions.solution:
The correct answer is C. 80,000 to 1,20,000.

Community Health Centres (CHCs) are the second tier of the healthcare infrastructure in India, catering to a larger population than Primary Health Centres (PHCs) and providing comprehensive healthcare services. The population coverage of a CHC is crucial in determining its capacity and resources to serve the community effectively.

Why the other options are not correct:

A. 40,000 to 60,000:This population range is typically covered by a Primary Health Centre (PHC), not a Community Health Centre (CHC). CHCs are designed to serve larger populations.

B. 60,000 to 80,000:While this population range is closer to the typical coverage of a CHC, it is still on the lower end. CHCs are generally established to serve larger populations than this range.

D. None:This option is incorrect because CHCs do cover a specific population range. They are an essential part of the healthcare infrastructure in India, providing secondary healthcare services to communities within a defined geographical area.

Therefore, option C, covering a population of 80,000 to 1,20,000, is the most appropriate population range for a Community Health Centre (CHC). This range ensures that the CHC has adequate resources and facilities to provide comprehensive healthcare services to a substantial number of people within its catchment area.

questions.text: High risk infants are all except
questions.solution:
Birth order 2 (Option D):

- Birth order alone (such as being the second child) is not considered a high-risk factor for infants. The order in which a child is born does not inherently increase the risk of health complications or developmental issues. Each pregnancy is unique, and factors such as maternal health, prenatal care, genetics, and environmental influences play more significant roles in determining the health outcomes of the infant.

High-risk infants are those who have a higher likelihood of experiencing health complications or developmental issues compared to the general population of infants.

Why the other options are not correct:

Twins (Option A):

- Twins are considered high-risk infants because multiple pregnancies, such as twins, pose increased health risks for both the babies and the mother. Twins are more likely to be born prematurely, have low birth weights, and experience other complications compared to singletons.

Underweight (Option B):

- Infants born with low birth weight (underweight) are at a higher risk of health complications, including respiratory distress syndrome, infections, and developmental delays. Low birth weight is a well-established high-risk factor for infants.

Working mother (Option C):

- While being a working mother does not inherently make the infant high risk, it can impact factors such as access to prenatal care, maternal stress levels, and potential exposure to environmental hazards in the workplace. These factors may indirectly influence the infant's health outcomes.

In summary, option D (Birth order 2) is the correct answer because birth order alone is not considered a high-risk factor for infants. Options A, B, and C represent factors that are commonly associated with increased health risks for infants.

questions.text: Zinc deficiency is common in children from developing countries due to all the following except
questions.solution:
c. High incidence of intestinal parasitosis:This is the correct answer. Intestinal parasitosis, such as infections with parasites like Giardia lamblia or Ascaris lumbricoides, can lead to nutrient malabsorption and increased nutrient losses through diarrhoea, resulting in micronutrient deficiencies. However, intestinal parasitosis is not directly linked to zinc deficiency. Instead, it can contribute to deficiencies in other nutrients like iron and vitamin A.

Why the other options are not correct:

Zinc deficiency is indeed common in children from developing countries due to various factors.

a. Less consumption of animal food: Animal foods, such as meat, poultry, and seafood, are rich sources of zinc. In developing countries, where access to animal foods may be limited due to factors like economic constraints or cultural dietary practices, children may not consume enough zinc-rich foods, leading to a deficiency.

b. High dietary phytate content:Phytates are compounds found in plant foods like grains, legumes, and nuts. Phytates can bind to zinc and inhibit its absorption in the intestine. In diets high in phytate-rich foods, the bioavailability of zinc is reduced, increasing the risk of zinc deficiency, particularly in populations reliant on plant-based diets.

d. Frequent diarrheal episodes: Frequent diarrheal episodes can lead to increased zinc losses through stool, exacerbating zinc deficiency. Diarrhoea not only results in the loss of zinc but also impairs zinc absorption due to intestinal damage and inflammation. Therefore, children experiencing frequent diarrheal episodes are at higher risk of zinc deficiency.

In summary, options a, b, and d are all factors that contribute to zinc deficiency in children from developing countries, while option c (high incidence of intestinal parasitosis) is less directly associated with zinc deficiency and is more closely linked to other nutrient deficiencies resulting from malabsorption and increased nutrient losses.

choices.text: Diet, which contains variety of foods to safe guard from deficiencies
Diet on which a person or group lives
Diet which fulfils recommended daily allowances

questions.text: Prudent diet
questions.solution:
a. Diet for dietary goal achievement: a prudent diet is dietary recommendations or gaols set by an expert committee of WHO.

Why the other options are not correct:

b. Diet, which contains a variety of foods to safeguard from deficiencies:A prudent diet emphasizes the importance of consuming a diverse range of foods to ensure adequate intake of essential nutrients and to prevent deficiencies. By including a variety of foods in the diet, individuals can obtain a wide array of nutrients, vitamins, and minerals necessary for optimal health.

c. Diet on which a person or group lives:This option describes a general diet that individuals or groups follow as part of their regular eating habits. While a prudent diet may indeed be a part of someone's overall dietary pattern, it specifically emphasizes the importance of diversity and balance to promote health and prevent nutrient deficiencies.

d. Diet which fulfils recommended daily allowances:While meeting recommended daily allowances (RDAs) for essential nutrients is important, a prudent diet goes beyond simply meeting these minimum requirements. It focuses on consuming a balanced and varied diet that provides not only the essential nutrients but also other beneficial components of food, such as phytonutrients and antioxidants, which contribute to overall health and well-being.

questions.text: Disinfecting action of chlorine on water is mainly due to
questions.solution:
Chlorine is commonly used as a disinfectant in water treatment processes to kill or inactivate pathogenic microorganisms and prevent the spread of waterborne diseases. When chlorine is added to water, it undergoes various chemical reactions that produce disinfecting agents, primarily hypochlorous acid (HOCl) and hypochlorite ions (OCl-). However, the disinfecting action of chlorine on water is mainly attributed to hypochlorous acid.

Why the other options are not suitable:

A. Hydrogen chloride:Hydrogen chloride (HCl) is a gas that dissolves in water to form hydrochloric acid (HCl) rather than contributing directly to the disinfecting action of chlorine. Hydrochloric acid itself is not a disinfectant commonly used in water treatment processes.

C. Hypochlorite ions: Hypochlorite ions (OCl-) are formed when chlorine reacts with water, and they do contribute to the disinfecting action of chlorine. However, hypochlorous acid (HOCl) is considered to be a more effective disinfectant than hypochlorite ions. Hypochlorous acid is a stronger oxidizing agent and is more effective at penetrating microbial cell walls to disrupt cellular processes and kill microorganisms.

D. Hydrogen ions:Hydrogen ions (H+) are also formed when chlorine is added to water, contributing to the acidity of the solution. While the pH of the water can influence the disinfecting action of chlorine, hydrogen ions themselves do not directly contribute to the disinfection process.

In summary, option B (Hypochlorous acid) is the correct choice because hypochlorous acid is the primary disinfecting agent formed when chlorine is added to water, and it is more effective at killing microorganisms compared to hypochlorite ions. While hypochlorite ions also contribute to disinfection, hypochlorous acid is considered the predominant active species responsible for the disinfecting action of chlorine in water treatment. Options A, C, and D do not accurately represent the main disinfecting agent formed by chlorine in water.

questions.text: Daylight factor in living room should be
questions.solution:
The daylight factor is a measure of the amount of natural daylight that penetrates into a room or space compared to the total amount of daylight available outside. It is expressed as a percentage and is used to evaluate the adequacy of natural lighting in indoor environments, particularly in architectural design and building planning.

a. 8%:This option suggests that the daylight factor in a living room should be 8%. This value represents a moderate amount of natural daylight penetration, which is typically considered sufficient for providing comfortable illumination and reducing the need for artificial lighting during daylight hours. An 8% daylight factor ensures that the living room receives adequate natural light without excessive glare or heat gain.

Why the other options are not suitable:

b. 6%:While a 6% daylight factor may still provide some natural light in a living room, it is lower than the recommended value of 8%. In spaces with a 6% daylight factor, occupants may experience dimmer lighting conditions and may rely more heavily on artificial lighting to supplement illumination, especially in areas further away from windows or daylight openings.

c. 10%:A daylight factor of 10% represents a higher level of natural daylight penetration than the recommended value of 8%. While greater daylight penetration can be beneficial for enhancing visual comfort and reducing energy consumption for lighting, a 10% daylight factor may also increase the risk of glare and heat gain in some situations, particularly if not properly managed through shading or window treatments.

d. 15%:A daylight factor of 15% is significantly higher than the recommended value of 8% for a living room. While greater daylight penetration can offer advantages such as improved mood, productivity, and energy efficiency, excessively high daylight levels may lead to issues such as glare, discomfort, and potential damage to furnishings or artwork from UV exposure. Therefore, a 15% daylight factor may be more appropriate for spaces with specific daylighting requirements, such as offices, classrooms, or art galleries, rather than residential living rooms.

In summary, option a (8%) is the correct choice for the daylight factor in a living room, as it provides a balanced level of natural daylight penetration for comfortable and energy-efficient indoor lighting.

questions.text: All the following methods are anti-larval except
questions.solution:
d. Pyrethrum:Pyrethrum is a natural insecticide derived from the flowers of certain species of chrysanthemum. While pyrethrum is highly effective against adult mosquitoes and other insects, it is not typically used to target mosquito larvae. Pyrethrum primarily acts as a contact insecticide, affecting insects upon direct contact with the substance. It is less effective in water environments where mosquito larvae reside. Therefore, pyrethrum is not considered an anti-larval method but rather an adulticidal or insecticidal method.

Why the other options are not suitable:

a. Intermittent irrigation:Intermittent irrigation involves alternating periods of flooding and drying in agricultural fields to disrupt the breeding sites of mosquitoes. This method is effective in controlling mosquito larvae because it disrupts their habitat and prevents them from completing their life cycle. Therefore, intermittent irrigation is considered an anti-larval method.

b. Paris green: Paris green is a toxic substance containing copper (II) acetate and arsenic (III) acetate. It has been historically used as an insecticide, including for controlling mosquito larvae. Paris green works by poisoning the larvae when they come into contact with the treated water. Therefore, Paris green is also an effective anti-larval method.

c. Gambusia affinis:Gambusia affinis, commonly known as the western mosquitofish, is a species of fish that feeds on mosquito larvae. Introducing Gambusia affinis into water bodies containing mosquito larvae can significantly reduce mosquito populations as the fish consume the larvae. Therefore, Gambusia affinis is considered an anti-larval method.

In summary, option D is the correct answer because pyrethrum is not an anti-larval method, unlike the other options which are all effective in controlling mosquito larvae.

questions.text: PHC is designed as Type A if it conducts less than _____ specified number of deliveries
questions.solution:
Primary Health Centres (PHCs) are an integral part of the healthcare infrastructure, especially in rural areas, providing essential primary healthcare services to the population. The categorization of PHCs into Type A, B, or C depends on various factors, including the number of deliveries conducted.

Why the other options are not correct:

A. 10: This number is too low to be considered a threshold for categorizing a PHC as Type A. PHCs typically handle a higher volume of deliveries to serve the needs of the population adequately.

B. 15: Similar to option A, 15 deliveries are also insufficient to categorize a PHC as Type A. PHCs are expected to handle a larger caseload to qualify for this classification.

C. 30: While 30 deliveries might be a significant number for a smaller healthcare facility, it is not typically the threshold for categorizing a PHC as Type A. PHCs often handle more deliveries than this before being classified into a higher type.

Therefore, option C, 20 deliveries, is the most appropriate threshold for determining the classification of a PHC as Type A. If a PHC conducts fewer than 20 deliveries, it is considered Type A, indicating that it may have limited facilities for childbirth and may need to refer complicated cases to higher-level healthcare facilities

choices.text: Killing power of a disease in a time
Killing power of a disease with no time interval

questions.text: Case fatality rate is
questions.solution: • CFR gives killing power of disease. Usually time frame is not specified

questions.text: Silent epidemic of century
questions.solution: Stroke, cognitive decline and vascular dementia are known as the silent epidemic of the 21st century.

choices.text: Causal relationship between exposure and effect

questions.text: Chi-square test is used to measure the degree of
questions.solution:
The chi-square test is a statistical test used to determine whether there is a significant association or relationship between two categorical variables. It assesses whether the observed frequencies of the categories in a contingency table differ significantly from the frequencies that would be expected under the assumption of independence between the variables.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - The chi-square test does not measure causal relationships between exposure and effect. It only assesses whether there is an association between two categorical variables. Determining causality requires further study designs, such as randomized controlled trials or observational studies with appropriate control for confounding factors.

Option C - Correlation measures the strength and direction of the linear relationship between two continuous variables. The chi-square test is not used to measure correlation between variables; it specifically deals with categorical variables, not continuous ones.

Option D - The chi-square test is not used to measure agreement between two observations. Agreement between observations typically involves comparing categorical data using measures such as Cohen's kappa for inter-rater agreement or intra-class correlation coefficients for agreement between continuous measurements.

Therefore, the most appropriate interpretation of the chi-square test is that it measures the degree of association between two categorical variables. It assesses whether there is a significant relationship between the variables beyond what would be expected by chance.

questions.text: If the prevalence of a disease is 10%, the probability that either one among three will have diabetes
questions.solution:
To find the probability that at least one person among three will have diabetes, we can use the complement rule, which states that the probability of an event happening is equal to 1 minus the probability of the event not happening.

Given:

Prevalence of the disease (diabetes) = 10% = 0.10

Number of people selected at random = 3

The probability that none of the three people have diabetes can be calculated using the binomial probability formula:

P (none have diabetes) = (1 - 0.10)₃= 0.90₃= 0.729

Therefore, the probability that at least one person among the three will have diabetes is:

P (at least one has diabetes) = 1 - P(none have diabetes) = 1 - 0.729 = 0.271

Rounding off =0.3

So, the probability that either one among three will have diabetes is approximately 0.3, which corresponds to option (b).

choices.text: It indicates degree of association between 2 characteristics
Correlation coefficient of 1 means that two variables exhibit linear relationship

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about correlation
questions.solution:
Correlation measures the degree and direction of the association between two variables. It quantifies how one variable change when the other variable changes. However, correlation does not measure risk. Risk is typically assessed using measures such as relative risk, odds ratio, or hazard ratio, depending on the context of the study.

Explanation as to why the other options are not correct:

a) It indicates the degree of association between 2 characteristics.

This statement is true. Correlation measures the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables.

b) Correlation coefficient of 1 means that two variables exhibit a linear relationship.

This statement is true. A correlation coefficient of +1 indicates a perfect positive linear relationship, where an increase in one variable corresponds to a proportional increase in the other variable. Similarly, a correlation coefficient of -1 indicates a perfect negative linear relationship.

d) Causation implies correlation.

This statement is not universally true. While correlation can suggest a potential relationship between variables, it does not imply causation. Correlation only measures the association between variables, but it does not prove that changes in one variable cause changes in another variable. Causation requires additional evidence from experimental studies or rigorous observational studies with appropriate control for confounding factors.

questions.text: Power of study can be increased by
questions.solution:
The power of a statistical test is the probability of correctly rejecting a false null hypothesis, or in other words, the ability of the test to detect a true effect if it exists. Increasing the power of a study is desirable because it reduces the likelihood of committing a Type II error (false negative), thereby increasing the chances of detecting a true effect when one exists.

b) Decreasing β error:The β error, or Type II error rate, is the probability of failing to reject a false null hypothesis. Decreasing the β error rate would reduce the likelihood of failing to detect a true effect, thereby increasing the power of the study. This is because a lower β error rate means a higher probability of correctly rejecting a false null hypothesis, which is indicative of greater sensitivity in detecting true effects. Therefore, this option is correct.

Explanation as to why the other options are not correct:

a) Increasing α error:The α error, or Type I error rate, is the probability of rejecting a true null hypothesis. Increasing the α error rate would lead to a higher likelihood of falsely rejecting a true null hypothesis, which can increase the chance of Type I errors but does not directly increase the power of the study. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

c) Decreasing α error: Similar to option a, decreasing the α error rate does not directly increase the power of the study. While reducing the α error rate decreases the likelihood of Type I errors, it does not affect the ability of the study to detect true effects. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

d) Increasing β error:Increasing the β error rate would have the opposite effect of decreasing study power. A higher β error rate means a higher probability of failing to detect a true effect when one exists, leading to a decrease in study power. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

In summary, the correct answer is option b, as decreasing the β error rate directly increases the power of the study by reducing the likelihood of Type II errors.

questions.text: The value of HDI in India is
questions.solution:
• HDI Value in India→0.633(In the year-2023)
  • India ranks 132 out of 191 countries
  • Norway > Switzerland > Ireland

questions.text: Specificity of a screening test is the ability of a test to detect _____________
questions.solution: • Specificity of a screening test is the ability of the test to identify those who don't have the disease or true negatives.

questions.text: The most sensitive test to detect argemone oil is:
questions.solution:
a. Paper chromatography: Paper chromatography is highly sensitive and widely used in separating and detecting components in a mixture. It offers excellent resolution and can detect even small amounts of substances. Argemone oil can be identified based on its characteristic chromatographic profile. Therefore, this option is correct.

Why the other options are not correct:

b. Nitric acid test:The nitric acid test involves adding nitric acid to the oil sample, which causes the formation of a yellow coloration if argemone oil is present. However, this test may not be as sensitive or specific as the Paper chromatography and may give false-positive results in the presence of other substances.

c. Nalgonda technique: The Nalgonda technique is used for detecting adulteration of edible oils with argemone oil. It involves colour changes upon addition of sulfuric acid to the oil. While it is specific for argemone oil, it may not be as sensitive as paper chromatography in detecting trace amounts of argemone oil.

d. Methylene blue reduction test:The methylene blue reduction test is used to detect the presence of mineral oil in edible oils. It involves adding methylene blue dye to the oil sample and observing the rate of reduction of the dye due to the presence of reducing agents, such as unsaturated fatty acids. This test is not specific for detecting argemone oil and may not be as sensitive as the Nalgonda technique.

In summary, option a) (Paper chromatography) is the correct answer because it is the most sensitive and specific test for detecting the presence of argemone oil in edible oils. Options b), c), and d) may also be used for this purpose but may not offer the same level of sensitivity or specificity.

questions.text: Learned behaviour which is socially acquired is known as
questions.solution:
The correct answer is D. Culture.

Culture (Option D): Culture is a broad and comprehensive term that includes the entire range of learned behaviours, beliefs, customs, values, and practices within a society. It encompasses both material and non-material aspects of life and is socially acquired and transmitted.

Why the other options are not suitable:

Customs (Option A): Customs refer to traditional practices or behaviours that are commonly accepted within a specific social group. While customs are part of culture, they alone do not encompass the entirety of learned behaviour.

Acculturation (Option B): Acculturation is the process of cultural exchange that occurs when two or more cultural groups come into contact. It involves the exchange of cultural elements, but it does not represent the entire set of learned behaviours within a particular society.

Standard of living (Option C): Standard of living refers to the level of comfort, wealth, material goods, and necessities available to individuals or a group. It is an economic indicator rather than a comprehensive term for socially acquired behaviours.

Given that the question specifically asks about learned behaviour that is socially acquired, the most appropriate term is Culture (Option D).

questions.text: Following earthquake in Pakistan, which of the following vaccines is recommended by WHO?
questions.solution:
After earthquakes or other natural disasters, ensuring access to safe water, sanitation, shelter, and medical care are among the top priorities for relief efforts. Vaccination campaigns may be conducted in certain circumstances to prevent outbreaks of vaccine-preventable diseases. However, the specific vaccines recommended by the World Health Organization (WHO) depend on various factors, including the prevailing health risks, the population affected, and available resources.

Explanation for why the other options are not correct:

a. Typhoid vaccine:Typhoid fever is a bacterial infection transmitted through contaminated food and water. Following an earthquake, there may be disruptions to water and sanitation systems, increasing the risk of waterborne diseases like typhoid. In some situations, the WHO may recommend vaccination against typhoid to prevent outbreaks among displaced populations living in crowded conditions with limited access to clean water and proper sanitation.

b. Cholera vaccine: Cholera is another waterborne disease caused by the bacterium Vibrio cholerae. Like typhoid fever, cholera outbreaks can occur in the aftermath of natural disasters, especially when sanitation infrastructure is compromised and access to safe drinking water is limited. In such situations, vaccination campaigns targeting at-risk populations may be considered as part of comprehensive cholera control efforts.

c. Tetanus vaccine: Tetanus is a bacterial infection caused by Clostridium tetani, which can enter the body through wounds or cuts contaminated with soil, dust, or feces containing the bacterium. In the immediate aftermath of earthquakes or other disasters, injuries and wounds are common due to collapsing buildings, falling debris, and other hazards. Ensuring access to tetanus vaccination and wound care is essential to prevent tetanus infections among those injured during the disaster.

While all of these vaccines may be important in certain disaster response scenarios, the specific recommendation depends on the context and assessment of the health risks by public health authorities and organizations like the WHO. Therefore, the correct answer is "None of the above" because the question does not specify the context or recommendations made by WHO following the earthquake in Pakistan.
